segments.description:
Completed as stone dust by town of Wayland.
DCR to pave as part of Wayland to Sudbury project.

segments.name: Gloria Braunhardt Bike Path
segments.description: Part of Little River Trail System.

segments.name: BFRT Phase 2D
segments.description:
Phase 2D covers 4.9 miles from the previous terminus in Concord to the junction with the MCRT. The trail opened in June 2025 for public use but “at your own risk”.
The Town is waiting for the State to finalize the current contract and transfer responsibility for maintenance of the trail over to the Town. This was once expected in September 2025, the official date of the transfer to Sudbury is now unknown.

links.text: BFRT Phase 2D Map, with parking, etc.

segments.name: Phase 1 - Berlin Rail Trail
segments.description: This phase is the westernmost end of the MCRT Wayside section and would extend the trail from the Hudson town line to Coburn Rd. It would be the longest section in Berlin, likely the easiest to construct, and would immediately add contiguous miles to the rapidly developing eastern section of the MCRT.

links.text: Mountain Biking - Ross Flood Control (Access to ↓)

segments.name: Watch Factory Riverwalk
segments.description: This section was created by the Watch Factory Lofts. The outside boundary of the Riverwalk is marked by a blue line.

segments.name: Worcester to Millbury segment
segments.description: Starting at the northern end of the Blackstone Heritage Corridor, the Worcester, MA, to Millbury, MA, segment is 2.5 miles long, starting at the Blackstone River Valley Heritage Center at Worcester (3 Paul Clancy Way). This stretch offers two bike repair stations, including one at the Heritage Center and another at the 1265 Millbury Street parking lot in Worcester.

segments.name: Phase 2 - Belmont Community Path
segments.description: Route shown is one option.

links.text: Mountain Biking - Rock Meadow Conservation Area

segments.name: Neponset River Greenway: With Pope John Paul II Park, Joseph Finnegan Park, River Boardwalk, and Harvest River Bridge
Georgetown-Boxford section of Border to Boston Trail
segments.description:
Singletrack through utility corridor. Some stream crossings have fairly precarious bridges where bikes must dismount and walk across.
The MassDOT project to improve this segment of the Border to Boston Trail includes a portion of the Georgetown Rail Trail and a portion of the Boxford Rail Trail.

segments.name: MCRT, Ware River Park in Gilbertville
segments.description: A portion of this trail was first opened as the Gilbertville Fitness Trail. Owned by the Town of Hardwick. Opened with funding support from Mass Trails Program and in collaboration with the East Quabbin Land Trust.

segments.name: Sconset Path (aka Milestone Road Path)
segments.description: A nice 6 mile path that connects midtown to Sconset. It starts at the Milestone Rotary and goes all the way Milestone Road to the Sconset Rotary on Main Street Sconset.

segments.name: Border Road to Beaver Street - Waltham
segments.description:
2.75 miles, Border Street to Linden Street Bridge, and Linden Street Bridge to Beaver Street. Constructed by the City of Waltham and maintained by DCR.
The Linden Street Bridge restoration is a separate DCR project and bisects the trail until anticipated summer/fall 2025 project completion.

links.text: Friends of the Mary Ellen Welch Greenway

segments.name: Cochituate Rail Trail
segments.description: The Cochituate Rail Trail is a beautifully-designed and functional 4 mile shared use path, connecting Natick's vibrant downtown with the Natick Mall and Golden Triangle, crossing Routes 9 and 30 to connect to Framingham's already completed portion that ends in Saxonville Village.

segments.name: Somerville Community Path Extension
segments.description: The Somerville Community Path Extension (CPX) was opened in June 2023 as part of the MBTA Green Line Extension (GLX) / rails with trails project. It includes a 1,400 feet long, 50 feet high truss bridge over the MBTA Fitchburg Line and Green Line tracks.

segments.name: Riverside Park Connector Trail
segments.description: begin at the back of the park and stretch along the rivers shoreline and through the woods for about a half mile to the Groveland (Bates) Bridge. The 10-foot wide nature trail will split into two paths at various points, he said, providing a disability-accessible asphalt surface on one stretch and a stone-dust or natural dirt surface on another. Construction on the trail is scheduled to begin next spring (2024) and it is expected to open by June 30 2024

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Belmont Community Path Connection
segments.description: This segment has been proposed since 1997.

segments.name: Bartlett Road Path
segments.description:
Length: 1.1 miles
Level of difficulty: easy
Take this midtown path to go to:
Winter Park & Playground
Miacomet Golf Club

segments.name: Surfside Road Path
segments.description:
Length: 2.2-miles
Level of difficulty: easy
The multi-use path starts at the Nantucket High School on 10 Surfside Road and takes you to one of Nantucket's most popular beaches, Surfside.
Stops along the way:
45 Surfside 
The Muse 
Yummy Nantucket
Skate Park / Nantucket Ice via Backus Lane 
The Surf at Surfside

segments.name: Sudbury to Wayland
segments.description: This project includes the renovation of the timber railroad bridge over the Sudbury River, and a timber lookout of the Great Meadows National Wildlife Refuge. It is the last, 1.4 mile gap before the Mass Central Rail Trail - Wayside, the Assabet River Rail Trail, and the Bruce Freeman Rail trail form more than 40 miles of a rail trail network spanning Waltham to the East, Marlborough to the West, and Lowell to the North, with more to come.

segments.name: Old Colony Nature Pathway
segments.description: A portion of the Wellfleet to Provincetown branch of the former Old Colony Rail Trail. Now a popular walking and bird watching area, Old Colony Nature Pathway is just under 1.5 miles long, alternating between sand and slightly packed dirt.

segments.name: The Norwottuck Branch of the Mass Central Rail Trail
segments.description: The Norwottuck Branch of the Mass Central Rail trail is an 11 mile DCR State Park built in 1993. A highlight is the Norwottuck Rail Trail Bridge, a 1492 foot, eight-span steel lattice truss bridge over the Connecticut River.

segments.name: Mass Central Rail Trail - Sterling Spur
Linden Street Bridge
segments.description: The bridge was opened December 24, 2025, after construction setup began in February 2025. The ramp on the west side was built in 2023. The bridge project also included some safety improvements at the Beaver Street intersection, the eastern terminus of the MCRT-Wayside.

segments.name: BRFT Phase 1
segments.description: Phase 1 of the Bruce Freeman Rail Trail extends from the Lowell/Chelmsford line near Cross Point and Rt. 3, through Chelmsford Center, to the intersection of Route 27 and Route 225 in Westford. It traverses woods, wetlands, open fields, recreational areas, and shopping areas. This section is is 6.8 miles long.

links.text: BFRT Phase 1 & 2A Map, with parking, bathrooms, etc.

segments.name: MCRT Waltham-Weston Phase 1 with Stony Brook Bridge
segments.description: This 0.3 mile trail includes the Stony Brook Bridge, a steel riveted lattice truss bridge built in 1896. The bridge crosses over the MBTA Fitchburg Commuter Rail Line. Opened in August 2025.

links.text: DCR Instagram video: Pouring the concrete deck

segments.name: Dorchester Greenway
segments.description:
The Dorchester Greenway is a community-led vision for a 0.7 mile long off-road bicycle and pedestrian path on top of the MBTA’s Red Line tunnel, between Ashmont Station and Park Street.

The proposed Dorchester Greenway would extend in both directions from the existing plaza at Shawmut Gardens.

segments.name: Neponset Trail Extension
segments.description: 0.7 mile extension from Tenean Beach area to Morrissey Boulevard along I-93. Includes a 670-foot boardwalk elevated over a small section of salt marsh and tidal flats

segments.name: Hyde Park to Blue Hills
segments.description: A proposed extension from the end of the Neponset Greenway toward the Blue Hills.

segments.name: Charles River Connector and Pocket Park
segments.description: Connection between the Charles River and Watertown-Cambridge Greenway. A narrow quiet boardwalk and a traffic signal make this connection easy. North Beacon street has very wide buffered bike lanes too.

links.text: Not just another walk in the (pocket) park

segments.name: Trolley Brook Trail
segments.description: The Trolley Brook section of the Ashland Upper Charles Trail is constructed on an existing rail trail. The trail, roughly 1/2 mile long, runs from Memorial Drive (formerly referred to as the MBTA Access Rd.), just south of the Middle School fields, to Megunko Rd. near Stone Park in downtown Ashland. It includes some beautiful scenery: woodlands, a stream and a pond. The surface is now wheelchair accessible!

links.text: Friends of the Ashland Upper Charles Trail

segments.name: Norton Mansfield Rail Trail
segments.description: A paved 5 mile path from the World War II Memorial Trail in Mansfield (1.6 miles) to the Taunton border. Has a short on road section over I-495, but it is a nice bi-direction bike lane with flex posts.

segments.name: Norton Rail Trail
segments.description: A nice bidirectional bike lane with flex posts

segments.name: Lynnfield Rail Trail - Phase 1
segments.description: 1.8 miles.

segments.name: Lynnfield-Wakefield Rail Trail - Phase 2
segments.description: 0.7 miles in Lynnfield and 0.3 miles in Wakefield. A portion of the rail trail will go through Reedy Meadow via an elevated boardwalk.

segments.name: Cambridge - Muddy River Route
segments.description:
A popular route to access Comm Ave and the BU Bridge from the Muddy River.

The Carlton Street footbridge provides a nice ramp over the Green Line tracks. Carlton Street itself does not have a dedicated bike lane, until north of Beacon street. There is then a nice contraflow route through the quiet Cottage Farm Historic District, which leads to the bike lanes on Comm Ave and the BU bridge.
Parkway Road and Netherlands Road both have contraflow bike lanes, so you can go either way around this block. Take care when crossing Brookline Ave.

segments.name: Wakefield Rail Trail
segments.description: This 0.91 mile portion of the Wakefield Rail Trail was paved by National Grid as part of the Woburn to Wakefield underground electric transmission line installation within the MBTA ROW.

segments.name: Northern Georgetown to Byfield section of Border to Boston Trail
Green Street Connector Project & Route 117 (Main Street) Bridge Replacement Project
segments.description:
The Green Street Connector Project will create a new north-south roadway between Route 117 and the Route 20 rotary. It includes the construction of a shared use path along the Green Street Connector, providing one part of an interim connection of the Massachusetts Central Rail Trail (MCRT) through the project limits.
The Route 117 (Main Street) Bridge Replacement project, including the construction of a shared use path, provides the other part of the interim connection of the MCRT. This bridge is a MassDOT Project.
The Green Street Connector Project and the Route 117 Bridge Replacement project are both part of the larger Route 128/i-95 Corridor Plan.
The following Mass Central Rail Trail Weston-Waltham Phase 2 project rehabilitating the railroad bridge over Route 128 will likely not proceed without the completion of the Green Street Connector and Route 117 Bridge Replacement projects.

links.text: MCRT Waltham – Weston Phase 2 Status Update, January 2025
Page 154: Route 128/i-95 Land Use & Transportation Study / Green Street Connector

segments.name: Wachusett Dam Hike: DCR River Road
segments.description: This section of the Wachusett Dam Hike is River Road, gated closed to vehicles, and open to pedestrians and bikes. Not the original railroad corridor. Access at DCR yellow Gate Number 43 from the east side of Lancaster Mill Pond at Route 62. An alternative access point is DCR yellow Gate Number 42 at Grove Street. An unnumbered yellow gate (DCR calls this "Gate Greyhound") is on the south side of the bridge over the Stillwater River, and it does not prohibit pedestrians or bicyclists. An unnumbered yellow gate (DCR calls this "Gate 10%" and it is labeled "C 8") continues to the next section of the Wachusett Dam Hike.

links.text: DCR - North Dike to the Dam
Image: Gate Number 43, Entrance at east side of Lancaster Mill Pond
Image: Gate Number 42, Entrance at west side of Lancaster Mill Pond
Image: Gate 10%, continuing trail to Gravel Path

segments.name: Wachusett Dam Hike: Gravel Path
segments.description: This section of the Wachusett Dam Hike is a gravel path with steep sections. Can be walked, mountain biked, or gravel biked. It would be difficult on a road bike and is not ADA accessible. Not the original railroad corridor. Heading east, an unnumbered yellow gate (DCR calls this "Gate 10%" and it is labeled "C 8") marks the transition to River Road.

links.text: DCR - North Dike to the Dam
Image: Gate 10%, continuing trail to River Road

segments.name: Minuteman/Linear Park Connector
segments.description: A 0.3 mile trail. This section runs along the bank of Yates Pond with a cantilever bridge, then on the east side of the main Alewife station, then between Jerry's Pond and the Russell Field entrance to Alewife station. The cantilever bridge and widening of the path were a portion of Cambridge's "Belmont - Cambridge - Somerville Path" project.

segments.name: MCRT Western Terminus
segments.description: The Mass Central Rail Trail's western terminus is at Union Station in Northampton.

segments.name: Clinton Build Phase 2
segments.description: The segment connects two town owned parcels – the Maffei Conservation Area and the Rauscher Farm. Construction funds have been awarded by MassTrails.

links.text: Map of Clinton Open Space including MCRT

segments.name: Mattapoisett Rail Trail, Phase 2B
segments.description: Opened in 2021. Also known as the Marion Connector.

segments.name: Phase 3 - Berlin Rail Trail
segments.description:
This phase will connect West Berlin to Clinton. Clinton is actively planning their section, including a 1,000-foot long tunnel, and potentially the Wachusett Reservoir dam and a new bridge as well.
Given the development in Clinton and the relative ease of constructing this stretch, it might make sense to do it before taking on the more daunting Phase 2.

segments.name: Phase 2 - Berlin Rail Trail
segments.description: This section presents unique challenges, following an uncertain path and navigating the complex Five Corners intersection, where only remnants of the old railroad bridge remain. However, it also offers an exciting opportunity to connect with the Lester G. Ross Dam and the Aqueduct Trail, adding to the already impressive network of major connecting paths along the MCRT.

segments.name: Riverside Square to India Point Park
segments.description: Phase 4 of East Bay Bike Path, complete in 1992

segments.name: Franklin Street to Independence Park
segments.description: Phase 3 - completed 1990 - (3.87 miles)

segments.name: Danvers Rail Trail | Northwest Extension - Phase 3
Rail Trail
segments.description: A 0.5-mile segment running from South River Street to Ocean Street. It follows the historic railroad bed through Pratt Farm, crosses the South River via the scenic Keville Footbridge (launch location for kayaks, canoes, SUPs), and ends at Dandelion Park. The section between Dandelion Park and the Keville Bridge is ADA accessible.

segments.name: Woonsocket to Cumberland section
segments.description: An 11-mile segment just over the Massachusetts border leads from Woonsocket, RI, to Cumberland, RI, passes by four rolling dams, and takes you through the Blackstone River State Park with a stop at the Capt. Wilbur Kelly House & Transportation Museum in Lincoln.

segments.name: North Adams Downtown Connector
segments.description: Brown Street to Heritage State Park. Includes rehab/reconstruction of pedestrian bridge over active CSX railroad

segments.name: Phase 4 - Ashuwillticook
segments.description: 25% design

segments.name: Phase 2 - Westborough
segments.description: The 25% preliminary design has been completed due to funding from MassTrails. Currently, the Town is also evaluating an alternative route that would take the trail off Meadow Road and behind Westmeadow Plaza. Once the evaluation is complete, more information will be shared. The next phase will include getting to 100% design and subsequent construction.

segments.name: Phase 6 - Westborough
segments.description: The Town is in the process of obtaining easements from property owners along this stretch.

segments.name: Riverside Square to Barrington County Road
segments.description: Phase 1 - completed in 1987 - (4.17 miles)

segments.name: Barrington River and Palmer River Bridges
segments.description: The bridges, which date back to the 1880s, have been closed since 2019 because they were badly deteriorated. Each new bridge will be approximately 300 feet long and 14 feet wide. They are expected to reopen in 2026

links.text: RIDOT - East Bay Bike Path Bridges Replacement Project

segments.name: Nauset Bicycle Trail
segments.description: The Nauset Bike Trail is one of three bike trails at Cape Cod National Seashore. This 1.6-mile trail connects the Salt Pond Visitor Center to Coast Guard Beach, passing through pine forests and sandy dunes. Enjoy a nice afternoon bike ride and then cool off at the beach!

segments.name: Phase 1 - Westborough
segments.description: Currently BWALT is part of a larger project (Otis Street Improvements). At 75% design and scheduled for construction in Summer 2025.

segments.name: Phase 2 - Protection Ave to Brown Street
Bridle Path
segments.description: A 2.5-mile stretch of trail from Pinehurst Road to South River Street, this wide, flat, stone-dust path is ideal for walking, running, biking, and horseback riding. It meanders through quiet woods, alongside farmland, and near Marshfield's Fairgrounds and sand & gravel pits. The trail intersects several roads with clear markings and connects to Carolina Hill Reservation.

segments.name: Phase 4 - Westborough
segments.description: The Town is in the process of obtaining easements from property owners along this stretch.

segments.name: Phase 3 - Westborough
segments.description: The Town is in the process of obtaining easements from property owners along this stretch. There is an existing trail section between East Main Street and Lyman Street. The property owners at 18 and 30 Lyman Street have dedicated to build a portion of the trail as part of a Planning Board Special Permit approval.

segments.name: Loop Trail
segments.description: 5.5 mile loop

segments.name: County Road to Franklin Street
segments.description: Phase 2 - completed 1989 - 2.38 miles

segments.name: Lowell Connector Trail
segments.description:
A 0.35 mile connector under the Lowell Connector highway. It runs from the parking lot terminus of BFRT and continuing toward Target.
Though once considered as part of the Bruce Freeman Rail Trail, ultimately the Lowell Connector Trail did not become an extension of the BFRT; as it is solely the plan, design and construction by the city of Lowell. However, the trail provides a link to the city for those using the BFRT, and the city hopes to connect this trail to other trails in Lowell in the future.

links.text: Fall/Winter 2024 BFRT Newsletter: Connector Trail Links Lowell to BFRT

segments.name: Northampton Rail Trail System - New Haven & Northampton Canal Greenway section
Belchertown MCRT 1C
segments.description: This 1.3 mile section of the Belchertown Greenway and Mass Central Rail Trail is in design and on the MassDOT 2029 TIP for construction. MassDOT calls the project "MCRT, Section 1C".

segments.name: The Wachusett Aqueduct
segments.description: The Wachusett Aqueduct is a grass-covered surface that is open to the public. One day, it will connect the Berlin Rail Trail section of the Mass Central Rail Trail to the Boston Worcester Air Line Trail

segments.name: Salem Street to Lynnfield-Wakefield Rail Trail
segments.description: This 0.7 mile segment is proposed.

segments.name: Phase 3 NHSG
segments.description: Planned for construction in 2030, along with segments north. No path exists currently

segments.name: Phase 2 NHSG - Seabrook
segments.description: The Seabrook section of the Greenway faces significant challenges, primarily due to the trail running through land owned by NextEra Energy, which operates the Seabrook Station nuclear power plant. Additionally, the Seabrook Board of Selectmen has not yet agreed to take on responsibility for the trail’s maintenance once it’s completed.

segments.name: Phase 1 NHSG
segments.description: An 8-mile stretch of rail trail running through Portsmouth and North Hampton, utilizing abandoned Pan Am Railways corridors. The trail features a stone dust surface approximately 12 feet wide, providing a scenic route through woods, neighborhoods, and natural areas like the Great Bog.

segments.name: Phase 1B NHSG
segments.description: A 1.9-mile stretch running from the Hampton/North Hampton town line to Drakeside Road, located on the west side of Route 1. The project involves significant environmental considerations, including wetland management and drainage challenges.

segments.name: Phase 3 NHSG
segments.description: There is a dirt path here. It'll be improved in 2030

segments.name: Palmer on street alternative
segments.description: From Belchertown MCRT to Ware town line - on street alternative

segments.name: Belchertown Greenway in use
segments.description: This section of the Belchertown Greenway includes the timber Trestle Bridge over Jabish Brook. While not yet improved, it is used by pedestrians and bicyclists.

segments.name: Detour
segments.description:
A grass path in the official Weston Trail Network through Sears Conservation Land.
Free parking is available at the Melone Homestead, at the end of a very long driveway off Crescent Street. Look for the "Land's Sake" banner by the mailbox labeled "27." Crescent Street is off Rt 20/Boston Post Road, east of Weston Center. See link below.

links.text: Weston Forest & Trail Association: Melone Homestead Map

segments.name: Detour
segments.description: A grass trail in the official Weston Trail Network, around the Weston Solar Landfill. Accessible from the Weston Transfer Station, after the MBTA Kendall Green station which has free parking.

links.text: This trail in the Weston Trail network

segments.name: Grand Junction Multi-Use Path
segments.description: This project is proposed, using the state owned Grand Junction Corridor.

segments.name: Marty Sender Riverwalk section of Charles River Bike Path
segments.description: Built in two phases, this project was a rehabilitation of the existing Charles River Bike Path section. Phase 1, 0.2 miles, was built in 2022, from the Cove playground south to near Chaske Ave. Phase 2, 0.25 miles, was built in 2024 with a 500 foot boardwalk, continuing south to Commonwealth Ave.

links.text: Marty Sender Riverwalk, now complete, offers nature walk with ‘wow’ factor

segments.name: Joseph Thompson Pedestrian Bridge
segments.description: DCR built this bridge in 2018, to replace a previous bridge that was dangerous for strollers and wheelchairs.

links.text: A New Footbridge Over the Charles

segments.name: Mary T. Early Footbridge and Charles River Bike Path access
segments.description: The bridge was installed in 2004 and repaired in 2021.

links.text: Waltham's Mary T. Early Footbridge Closed For Repairs

segments.name: Air Line State Park Trail North
segments.description: Connects to Southern New England Trunkline Trail in Massachusetts.

segments.name: Mount Feake Cemetery
segments.description: The cemetery allows people to walk and bike within it, but of course do so with respect. There's a well travelled path around the locked gate on the western end.
This segment is navigable but is much narrower than the paved sections and is no more than a dirt footpath atop the levee.

segments.name: River Road
segments.description: This road through Robinson State park is closed to car traffic and a nice windy route with some views of the Westfield River
Mostly quiet connection

segments.name: Western Ave & Court Street
segments.description: A separated shared-use path alongside Western Ave and Court Street from Westfield State toward downtown

segments.name: Route 30 - Weston
segments.description: Currently in the 75% design phase, Weston and MassDOT are developing plans for a shared-use path alongside Route 30 in Weston. Other projects could see this path extend into Newton and Natick.

segments.name: Norumbega Greenway
segments.description: A three-way partnership between the DCR,  the Town of Weston, and the Solomon Foundation. Howard Stein Hudson has been hired to design a shared-use path along Norumbega Rd from Route 30 to River Road.

links.text: Weston's request for a Norumbega Road Complete Street Study

segments.name: Hammond Pond Parkway Phase 1
segments.description:
Projected to complete in Fall 2025. DCR, with input from the City of Newton, is undertaking the first phase of improvements to Hammond Pond Parkway from Beacon Street to the Route 9 ramps on the parkway. Improvements include a shared pathway, new streetlights, a redesign of the bridge over the MBTA tracks to better accommodate pedestrians and cyclists, and a new landscaped buffer between the roadway and the shared use path.
Has access to Webster Woods conservation area, walking only.

segments.name: Brook Path Wellesley Trails
segments.description: Brook Path is the most popular bike path in the Wellesley Trail system due to it's flat and level surface.

segments.name: On Road Charles River Bike Path Connection to Marty Sender
segments.description:
A mostly low traffic road route to connect the Marty Sender Riverwalk (Charles River) in Newton to Waltham.
Car traffic increases at the Woerd Avenue bridge over the Charles River/Cram's Cove bridge.

segments.name: Commonwealth Avenue Carriageway Redesign
segments.description:
The Commonwealth Avenue Carriageway Redesign Project will redesign, reconstruct and restore a critical compromised segment of the Commonwealth Avenue Carriageway from Lyons Field to the Marriott.  The project will create new  green space and  add a continuous walking and bicycle path where the roadway currently exists by rerouting vehicular traffic from north of the median to the south.
Work is estimated to largely complete by December 2025.

links.text: Commonwealth Avenue Carriageway Redesign, City of Newton

segments.name: Auburn St @ Comm Ave Shared Use Path
segments.description: This roadway reconstruction project under construction includes a shared use path extension of the Commonwealth Avenue Carriageway Redesign (also under construction) to Norumbega Road and the DCR boathouse parking lot.

links.text: Auburn St @ Comm Ave Intersection, City of Newton

segments.name: Wellesley Cross Town Trail
segments.description: The segments of the Wellesley Cross Town Trail.
This roadway project, currently at 25% design, may include a Shared Use Path to connect the Auburn St @ Comm Ave Shared Use Path (under construction) with the Route 30 - Weston project (in design).
Suggested route between the New Boston Rail Trail and the Goffstown Rail Trail

segments.name: Piscataquag Rail Trail
segments.description: The Piscataquog Trail is a 10 ft wide, paved recreational trail linking the West Side of Manchester to downtown. Used by cyclists and pedestrians, the trail connects to the West Side Ice Arena, football, soccer, and softball fields. The fourth and final phase of the Piscataquog Trail was completed in early 2016 and provides a connection to the Goffstown Rail Trail.

links.text: Friends of the Goffstown Rail Trail

segments.name: Rockingham Recreational Rail Trail
segments.description: Dirt trail

segments.name: South Manchester Rail Trail
segments.description: Paved 10 foot wide trail
Pretty quiet connecting route

segments.name: Arborway Improvement Project
segments.description: DCR is undergoing a redesign on the Arborway, which is proposed to include a multi-use path linking the existing Jamaicaway bike path to the Southwest Corridor.

segments.name: Draw One Bridge
segments.description: Originally proposed as part of Big Dig mitigation, a bike/pedestrian bridge could connect the terminus of the Somerville Community path and Mass Central Rail Trail to downtown Boston. In early discussions of MBTA's replacement of this rail bridge, there were plans to include the path, however recent designs and grants from the federal government do not include the path.

segments.name: Cape Cod Rail Trail Phase 4 Proposal
segments.description: This route is proposed and not finalized.

links.text: Cape Cod Rail Trail Phase 4 Proposal

segments.name: Twin Cities Rail Trail | Phase 3
segments.description:
Opened November 14th, 2025. 
Extends the trail south to the old Leominster train station.

segments.name: Twin Cities Rail Trail | Phase 2
segments.description:
Construction began Fall 2025
Estimated completion within 3 years

segments.name: Phase 3 in Barnstable and Yarmouth
segments.description: Pre-construction activities commenced in 2024, and construction is anticipated to commence Spring 2025.

segments.name: Hammond Pond Parkway Phase 1
segments.description:
While still under construction, bikeable with signs marked "Use At Your Own Risk" by June 2025. DCR states the project is now scheduled to be completed in spring of 2026, but with much of the road paving, striping, lighting, signals, drainage, plantings, etc. to be completed by fall 2025. The Department of Conservation and Recreation (DCR) with input from the City of Newton is undertaking the first phase of improvements to Hammond Pond Parkway from Beacon Street to the Route 9 ramps on the parkway. Improvements include a shared pathway, new streetlights, a redesign of the bridge over the MBTA tracks to better accommodate pedestrians and cyclists, and a new landscaped buffer between the roadway and the shared use path.
Has access to Webster Woods conservation area, walking only.

links.text: Hammond Pond Parkway: Current News and Future Plans

segments.name: Washington Street Pilot Shared Use Path
segments.description: Note at the start and stop of the path, the path has a preexisting, adjacent sidewalk, and the protected path is a two-way bike lane. Most of the path has no adjacent sidewalk, and is marked as a shared use path.

links.text: Eyes On the Street: A New Path Connects Two Villages In Newton

segments.name: Brook Path Wellesley Trails
segments.description: Brook Path is the most popular bike path in the Wellesley Trail system due to it's flat and level surface.

segments.name: On Road Charles River Bike Path Connection to Auburndale Park
segments.description:
Part of the Upper Charles River Reservation West. Includes Forest Grove DCR Reservation. A mostly low traffic road route to connect the Auburndale Park (Charles River) in Newton to Waltham.
Car traffic increases at the Woerd Avenue bridge over the Charles River/Cram's Cove bridge.

segments.name: Woerd Ave. Boat Launch Accessable Trail
segments.description: A sign at the entrance notes this DCR trail was assessed in October 2024. It is 0.13 miles one way, with a 1% maximum slope, 1% maximum cross slope, minimum 8 feet trail width, stone dust surface, and no obstacles except possible puddle after rain.

segments.name: Wellesley Cross Town Trail
segments.description: The segments of the Wellesley Cross Town Trail.

segments.name: Watertown Branch Rail Trail
segments.description: This is a curb-separated, two direction bike lanes, and a sidewalk, leading into the Watertown-Cambridge Greenway.

segments.name: Upper Charles Trail Extension
segments.description:
The goal of this advocacy campaign is to extend the existing Upper Charles Trail (UCT) in Milford, Holliston, and Ashland the last two and a half miles through Sherborn to downtown Framingham. This could be accomplished in the short term with a rail-with-trail strategy to accommodate trains that occasionally use the tracks owned by CSX. In the long term it may be possible to purchase the entire corridor for walking, biking and conservation.
The future design would likely make use of the paved Dudley Road Multi Use Path, and possibly the Sudbury Aqueduct Trail to make the connection.

segments.name: Fresh Pond Bikeway
segments.description: A section of the Fresh Pond Bikeway loop around Fresh Pond. Highlighted because it links the Watertown-Cambridge Greenway to the Alewife Brook Parkway Path.

segments.name: Danehy Park Connector
segments.description:
The Danehy Park / New Street Connector multi-use path is an in-design bicycle and pedestrian path between Concord Avenue and Danehy Park. Construction is estimated Spring 2025.
After this construction, planning for connections to Sherman Street, and a bridge over the MBTA Fitchburg Line to Rindge Ave, are possible.

segments.name: Mystic to Charles Connector
segments.description: A feasibility study was performed in 2020. A final route has not been selected.

segments.name: Dudley Road Multi Use Path
segments.description: The Dudley Road Multi-Use Path in Framingham was opened in 2017. It passes the Sudbury Aqueduct Trail.

segments.name: Pigeon Hill Trail
segments.description: The Pigeon Hill Trail is included as part of the Newton-Weston bridge replacement/rehabilitation at I-90/I-95 for eight highway bridges. This project is anticipated to complete in 2030.

segments.name: Pony Truss Bridge and Riverside Park
segments.description: The Pony Truss Bridge was installed in 2021. The Pony Truss Trail itself, on the eastern side Charles River and completed in 2022, is a hiking trail.

segments.name: Alewife Brook Parkway Path
segments.description: Adjacent to Alewife Brook Parkway, a busy road. Portions of this are essentially a wider than average sidewalk and can feel cramped.

segments.name: Lake Cochituate Path
segments.description:
Lake Cochituate Path is a planned multi-use path that will connect neighborhoods in West Natick with the Cochituate Rail Trail and other destinations to the east of Lake Cochituate. The path would extend from Hartford Street Extension east of Speen Street, along the south side of Route 9, past the Springvale Water Treatment Plant, connecting with the CRT near its crossing at Route 9. 
Lake Cochituate Path is a MassDOT project. 25% Design was submitted by the engineering firm HNTB in May 2021. Construction using federal and state funding is currently scheduled to begin in 2025; this timetable is subject to change.

segments.name: Two Bridges Trail
segments.description: The two existing railroad bridges are unimproved and hikeable. There is a proposal to use the two bridges to create an ADA accessible trail. Riverside Greenway Working Group is seeking negotiation for funding of this trail infrastructure.

segments.name: Connection to Natick Center Station
segments.description: As part of the Natick Center Station Accessibility Improvements project, the Cochituate Rail Trail will be extended to Natick Center Station.

segments.name: Hammond Pond Parkway Phase 2
segments.description: DCR proposes continuing the Hammond Pond Parkway Phase 1 Shared Use Path to Horace James Circle. Presently not in DCR’s near-term capital plan. Phase II is in DCR’s Parkways Master Plan, but it is not presently on DCR’s high-priority parkway project list.

links.text: Hammond Pond Parkway: Current News and Future Plans

segments.name: Connector Road / CD Road Two-Way Bike and Pedestrian Way
segments.description: This two-way bike and pedestrian way may begin construction in 2028. Funding comes from the 2024 revision to the MBTA Riverside Station (Riverside 4.0) mixed use development proposal, approved by the Newton City Council in December 2025.

segments.name: Wonder Bread Spur
segments.description: The 0.2 mile Wonder Bread Spur of the Cochituate Rail Trail, in honor of the former Wonder Bread factory. Now connects to the Natick Mall.

segments.name: Depot Tunnel
segments.description:
Reopening the Depot Tunnel is a notable proposal of the Riverside Greenway. However, it would connect to Pony Truss Trail, which is a hiking trail.
Riverside Greenway Working Group is seeking negotiation for funding of this trail infrastructure.

segments.name: BFRT Phase 3, Framingham Phase 2
segments.description:
The Framingham section of the trail has been divided into two parts. The remaining 2 miles, Phase 2, will continue from Frost Street to Pleasant Street (near Rte. 9). Phase 2 has the added complication of two bridges. The Grove Street bridge will be replaced, and the bridge over the Mass Pike may need to be raised to meet current clearance standards. These  are some of the reasons MassDOT decided to break the construction of the trail in Framingham into two phases. Framingham has already requested that Phase 2 be considered by 
the MassDOT project review committee.
The overall conceptual design for Framingham (Phase 1 and Phase 2), known as 10% design, has been completed.

links.text: Friends of the BFRT, Spring/Summer 2025 Newsletter

segments.name: Lasell Boathouse / Recreation Road Bridge
segments.description:
The reconstruction of this pedestrian bridge, expected in Spring/Summer 2025, will be immediately used for access to the hiking-only, Pony Truss Trail, Riverside Park, and Pigeon Hill Park.
However, options to connect it to the Newton Commonwealth Avenue Carriageway via bike boulevards or quiet streets to extend the north/south river connection are under investigation.
The future Riverside Greenway vision is envisioned as having a multi-use portion, including the bridge, reaching into the Wellesley trails system.

links.text: Mending a Gap in the Riverside Greenway

segments.name: Auburndale Park
segments.description: Part of the Upper Charles River Reservation West. Adjacent to Flowed Meadow conservation area and Auburndale Playground, also known as The Cove.

segments.name: On Road - Comm Ave Carriageway to Boathouse Bridge
segments.description: In the future, this may be improved with bike lanes. The crossing at Commonwealth Avenue is currently busy, but will add a crosswalk as part of the Commonwealth Avenue Carriageway Redesign project under construction. The Auburn Street crossing is less busy, but has no crosswalk.

segments.name: Grove Street Shared Use Path and Separated Bike Lanes
segments.description:
The Grove Street separate-use trail may begin construction in 2028. Funding comes from the 2024 revision to the MBTA Riverside Station (Riverside 4.0) mixed use development proposal, approved by the Newton City Council in December 2025.
The project will be a shared use path on northern Grove Street, becoming a separated bike lane and pedestrian walkway from Riverside to Asheville Road, and becoming a multi-use path to the Lower Falls Community Center.

segments.name: Stringer Bridge
segments.description: Connects to the Charles River Path section of the Wellesley Trail System. A DCR connection between Newton and Wellesley.

segments.name: Clippership Connector
segments.description: Completed in July 2025, the Clippership Connector filled a critical gap in the Mystic River regional trail system.

links.text: MassDOT Public Meeting for Clipership Connector

segments.name: Mystic Way
segments.description: Travels through Veterans Memorial Park, Mystic River Reservation, and John D. Hand Memorial Bridge.

segments.name: Malden River Greenway
segments.description: Malden River Greenway and Woods Bridge West Shore Underpass

segments.name: Clippership Park
segments.description: Clippership Park and Krystle Campbell Peace Garden.

segments.name: Gilbertville-Ware on street alternative
segments.description: This road detour is required to connect the Gilbertville MCRT to the MCRT Expansion. Uses the scenic Ware-Hardwick Covered Bridge.

segments.name: Menameset Habitat at former Tanner-Hiller Airport
segments.description:
Current: Suggested for wide-tire bikes only, otherwise, consider the alternate, parallel road detour shown, through Route 32, Wheelwright Road/Barre Road.
Future: In addition to adding 2 miles to the Mass Central Rail Trail, the East Quabbin Land Trust, in partnership with Mass Audubon and the Massachusetts Department of Fish and Game, preserved over 100 acres of the former Tanner-Hiller Airport for a grassland bird habitat and wildlife management area in New Braintree & Barre, which otherwise could have been purchased for development.
The land protection also enabled the Wheelwright Pond Dam removal project to proceed. The dam removal allowed the Ware River to run free through Hardwick and New Braintree. This enhanced numerous rare mussel populations that occur where the tributary meets the Ware River, as well as allowing recreational paddling without portaging.

links.text: East Quabbin Land Trust: Conservation along the Ware River
MA Department of Fisheries and Wildlife: Menameset Habitat Restoration Project Summary

segments.name: Pelski Connector
segments.description: Connect Grenville Park to the MCRT. Town of Ware will be responsible.

segments.name: Ware on street alternative
segments.description: This is a detour for the MCRT gap in Ware.

segments.name: Grenville Park
segments.description: Continuing the road detour to connect the MCRT gap in Ware, in Grenville Park.

segments.name: Village Landing Park
segments.description: Village Landing Park and Woods Bridge E Shore Underpass.

segments.name: Ferry Street Extension
segments.description: Along Mill Pond
It's possible to cut through the parking lot to connect these segments

segments.name: Missing Bridge
segments.description: This missing rail bridge creates a gap over the Ware River.

segments.name: EQLT New Braintree - Barre Connector
segments.description: The best on-road route to connect these two East Quabbin Land Trust properties, until a bridge over the Ware River can be built.

segments.name: Belchertown Roads
segments.description: The best available road section to connect the Belchertown Greenway to the Norwottuck Branch of the MCRT.

segments.name: Barre Connector
segments.description: This is the road connection from the Wachusett Greenways MCRT in Barre to the MCRT East Quabbin Land Trust trail (currently unimproved) in Barre.

segments.name: Single Track
segments.description: Until the Pelski Connector is built, this is the single track method of connecting the MCRT to Grenville Park.

segments.name: Grand Junction Connector
segments.description: Placeholder route. The actual route has not yet been proposed. This route will be revised later in 2025, when the proposed route is revealed. See Grand Junction Connector website for details.

links.text: Gore Street Utility Construction and Road Reconstruction

segments.name: Clinton Build Phase 1: Trailheads
segments.description: The plan for Build Phase 1 is to fund the construction of two access points to the trail from Rauscher Farm and the new trail head at 447 Berlin Street. Both access points will provide accessible parking and signage that will direct visitors to the trailheads. These 2 trailheads will connect to area trails on Rauscher Farm and other marked area trails.

segments.name: Battle Road Trail
segments.description: The Battle Road Trail is the main multi use path in the Minute Man National Historical Park.

segments.name: Arsenal St to Coolidge Ave in Watertown
segments.description: This is a short connection between Arsenal St and Coolidge Ave. It is paved and has a center line.

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Fitchburg Connection 2/8
segments.description: Beaver Brook Reservation.

segments.name: Phase 2: South Street Connector
segments.description: The second phase of the Roslindale Gateway Path will create an ADA-accessible connection between the Arboretum Road Entrance and the intersection of Bussey Street and South Street.

segments.name: Phase 5: MBTA Parcel Path
segments.description:
The final phase aims to complete the Roslindale Gateway Path system by creating a shared-use path connection through a parcel of land south of the Arboretum owned by the MBTA.
The path will terminate at a proposed portal at the Roslindale Village Commuter Rail station—a critical point of connectivity for commuters and visitors arriving by public transportation.

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Fitchburg Connection 8/8
segments.description: Be cautious on Brighton Street or take sidewalk.

segments.name: Blackwell Footpath
segments.description:
Blackwell Footpath passes through an Urban Wild within the Arboretum known as Bussey Brook Meadow.
The construction of this accessible shared-use path in 2000 opened new access to the Arboretum for those arriving from the Forest Hills Station or visiting from nearby neighborhoods along Washington Street.

segments.name: Phase 4: Peters Hill
segments.description:
The Peters Hill section will incorporate the existing roadway within Peters Hill as part of the shared-use pathway. It will also establish a section of accessible shared-use pathway through the crab apple, dawn redwood, and oak collections in the southeast area of Peters Hill.
In 2020, the Arboretum installed a mulch path along the alignment of the proposed Peters Hill shared-use path section.
Once established, the final pathway will open breathtaking views of often-overlooked plant collections on Peters Hill (such as the dawn redwood grove seen in the distance here) and provide opportunities for educational experiences.

segments.name: Phase 1: Tupelo Path and Arboretum Road Entrance
segments.description:
Formerly known as the Green Link Path. The first phase of the Roslindale Gateway Path creates a new entrance at the end of Arboretum Road and a pathway connection to Blackwell Footpath through Bussey Brook Meadow.
Phase 1 opened in April 2025. An official block party/ribbon cutting are planned for Saturday, July 19 from 11am-2pm (rain date: Sunday, July 20 from 11am-2pm).

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Fitchburg Connection 6/8
segments.description: Cottage Street is a low traffic side street, but one way North. If heading South, first go West on Concord Ave bike lane (with flex posts), take crosswalk, use Concord Ave bike lane East (with flex posts) to Myrtle Street.

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Fitchburg Connection 3/8
segments.description: Beaver Brook Reservation, dirt path and pedestrian bridge.

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Fitchburg Connection 5/8
segments.description: School Street has a shared use path on South side of street.

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Fitchburg Connection 1/8
segments.description: This parking lot provides access to Beaver Brook Reservation with less traffic than Waverly Oaks Road.

segments.name: Phase 3: Archdale Connection
segments.description: The third phase of the Roslindale Gateway Path will create an ADA-accessible entrance at the Commuter Rail underpass at the intersection of Archdale Road/South Street, as well as a pathway connection from the new entrance to the intersection of Bussey Street and South Street.

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Fitchburg Connection 7/8
segments.description: Belmont High School has shared use path around Clay Pit Pond.

segments.name: Topsfield Linear Common
segments.description: Though not paved and all dirt, you can ride a road bike on it no problem.  28c tires work just fine.

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Fitchburg Connection 4/8
segments.description: Moraine Street is dead end to cars. Lexington Street is busy with Bike sharrows only (NOTE: If heading towards MCRT-Wayside, suggest dismount and take crosswalk at end of Lexington to Moraine). Sycamore Street is medium traffic but no bike infrastructure. Quick on/off Trapello Road (busy main road with low-quality bike lanes). Waverly Street is not high traffic but has no bike infrastructure.

segments.name: Kristen Crowley Trail
segments.description: Though not paved and all dirt, you can ride a road bike on it no problem.  28c tires work just fine.

segments.name: Brattle St Cambridge Protected Bikelane
segments.description: This is a protected bi-directional bikelane along Brattle St and Mt Auburn St in Cambridge.

segments.name: Taylor St in Watertown Protected Bikelane
segments.description: This is a very short stretch of protected and bi-directional bike lane along Taylor St in Watertown. It is possible that it will be part of the Watertown Community Path.

segments.name: David J. Beattie Park, Collins Cove Walkway, Bridge Street Sidepath
Sandwich Shared Use Path
segments.description: This brand-new 6.5-mile path runs alongside the Route 6 Service Road from Route 130 to Chase Road, and connects directly to the Cape Cod Canal bike path. It’s open and ready to be enjoyed by walkers, runners, cyclists, families, and folks of all ages.

segments.name: Detour Sudbury to Wayland
segments.description: The safest detour while awaiting the trail gap to be filled. Starting from Wayland in the East, you can use the pedestrian crossing to the Garden Center parking lot, which leads to the beautiful low-traffic Pelham Island Road. Landham Road is moderately busy with traffic and has a limited shoulder; a sidewalk on the west side of Landham Road is an option for more cautious cyclists. The south sidewalk on Boston Post Road/Route 20 in Sudbury is recommended for all riders, to connect back to the MCRT.

segments.name: Assabet River Multi-use Bridge & Trail
segments.description: This project is currently working towards the 25% design submission which will be submitted in the fall of 2025.

links.text: Assabet River Multi-use Bridge & Trail Project

segments.name: Lynn Shore and Nahant Beach Promenade
Draw 7 Park
segments.description:
DCR is planning a complete renovation of Draw Seven Park, in the Mystic River Reservation.  The park currently consists mainly of highly degraded lawn/playing field, a degraded shoreline, and a few amenities:  river path, fish pier, parking lot, and benches, and provides access to the Amelia Earhart (AE) Dam.  In order to meet the key goals, the entire site will be reconstructed.
One element of the project is multiple connections: links to both the new Draw Seven Park Path Extension (to Alford St. Charlestown), the proposed Mystic River Crossing pedestrian/bicycle bridge to Everett, and to the entire Mystic River Reservation.

segments.name: Edgewater Greenway
segments.description: Construction began in 2025. This project will open up nearly half a mile of riverfront to public access with a trail, stabilization of the CCC-built cobble wall with strategic lowering and openings to improve views and porosity, a viewing area, landscape restoration, and renovations to Kennedy Playground.

links.text: Greenway keeps growing; $9m in funding will extend trail deeper into Mattapan

segments.name: Pvt. Michael Bouthot Bicycle Path
segments.description: Next to a highway, but a paved shared use path and crosses the Veterans Memorial Bridge.

segments.name: Extension to Massachusetts/Rhode Island border
segments.description: This project adds a half-mile stretch to the Blackstone River Greenway, extending from the Saint Paul Street Bridge in the Town of Blackstone to the Rhode Island border.

segments.name: Mattapoisett Rail Trail On Road
segments.description: Use caution, on-road.

segments.name: Wellington Underpass
segments.description: Construction for this project is projected to begin Fall 2025

segments.name: On Road Mattapoisett
segments.description: Use caution, on road.

segments.name: Mattapoisett Rail Trail Phase 1
segments.description: 1.9 Miles, opened in portions: 2009 Fairhaven to Mattapoisett Neck Road. Next, "Shining Tides Mile" broke ground in Septmber 2019, was completed from Mattapoisett Neck Road to Reservation Road in July 2022, then the section to Goodspeed Island Road opened in April 2023.

segments.name: Carlton Street Footbridge
segments.description: Built in 1890, closed since 1976, and rebuilt in September 2023. Added ADA accessible ramps and a "bike channel" to walk bikes up and down the stairs.

segments.name: Redstone Rail Trail Phase 1
segments.description: The Redstone Rail Trail in East Longmeadow opened with a ribbon-cutting ceremony on 9/9/2010.  It covers a portion of the prior Boston and Maine Railroad track, extending from Denslow Road, crossing Industrial Drive and Chestnut Street, and continuing to Maple Street. Those streets have pedestrian crosswalks with on-demand flashing lights to warn traffic.

segments.name: Redstone Rail Trail phase 2
segments.description: An expansion to the existing Redstone Rail Trail in East Longmeadow, that extends from Denslow Road to Maple Street, to extend the Maple Street end to Westwood Avenue.

segments.name: Tammy Diorio Pedestrian Crossing
segments.description: Installed in May 2025, the Tammy Diorio Pedestrian Crossing, across the East Somerville MBTA Green Line Station, links Inner Belt Road in Somerville to the Somerville Community Path.

links.text: Arlington Makes Plans to Connect Minuteman, Mystic River Paths

segments.name: South Medford Connector
segments.description: MassDOT currently estimates the South Medford Connector will start construction in Spring 2029.

links.text: MassDOT site for South Medford Connector

segments.name: East Bay Bike Path on Road
GTT River Road Trail Extension
segments.description: Construction began in May 2025 thanks to a 2024 MassTrails grant award. This project will be for the construction of the regional Grand Trunk Trail from its current end at the intersection of River and Farquhar Roads out to Haynes Street, a distance of 2,200 feet. The trail will follow the existing historical GTT rail bed on portions of 1 and 9 River Road. A small parking lot will be located along the trail.

links.text: Construction of the Grand Trunk Trail extension

segments.name: On Road Detour MCRT Clinton to Wachusett Greenways
segments.description: For advanced cyclists. High traffic and no shoulder on Route 110/West Boylston Street. Steep hill in Sterling. Narrow bridge with high traffic on Beaman Street in West Boylston.

segments.name: On Road Detour MCRT Hudson to Berlin
segments.description: This route was derived from the 2024 RideN2B. It was modified to include a bit more of the Assabet River Rail Trail and some residential streets.

segments.name: Connecticut Riverwalk and Bikeway W Springfield Phase 2
Haverhill - Bradford - Groveland Rail Trail Connection
Phase 3
segments.description: Phase 3 will be the continuation from Haggetts Pond Road to Bellevue Road with a small parking lot on Bellevue Road. The details of this phase and timing are still in the planning phase.

segments.name: On Road Section
segments.description: Low stress, there are bike lanes on Sanddri Drive.

segments.name: Oak Bluffs to Edgartown
segments.description: The 6-mile, flat and easy bike path on Beach Road between Oak Bluffs and Edgartown is the Island's most popular ride, offering scenic views of Nantucket Sound and Sengekontacket Pond. Cyclists may loop back using bike paths on Edgartown-Vineyard Haven Road and County Road.

segments.name: North Station Lovejoy Wharf, Bill Russell Bridge Underpass, Boston Harborwalk North End
segments.description: The Bill Russell Bridge Underpass opened in June 2025.

segments.name: BFRT Phase 2A
segments.description: Bruce Freeman Rail Trail Phase 2A is 4.9 miles in Westford, Carlisle, and Acton.

links.text: BFRT Phase 1 & 2A Map, with parking, bathrooms, etc.

segments.name: Blue Heron Pedestrian Bridge
segments.description: The Blue Heron Bridge is a tied-arch steel bridge that opened in 2005. The steel was galvanized and painted both to blend into the environment and for durability.

segments.name: Detour for skinny tire bikes
segments.description: Alternative on-road route if rough-condition former Tanner-Hiller airport (to be improved) is too much for your bike.

segments.name: Rocky Hill Greenway Multi-Use Trail
segments.description: The project consists of the construction of 0.4 miles of multi-use trail starting at the Manhan Rail Trail traveling northerly to Rocky Hill Road. The proposed path will be 10 foot minimum width consisting of an asphalt mix riding surface. In addition, the proposed project will include the construction of parking, trail heads, and the installation of wood safety rail, safety signing, and pavement markings. Minor improvements will be made to 760' of Rocky Hill Road, including restriping for improved bicycle accommodations, improved sidewalk, and wheelchair ramps.

links.text: Construction under way on Rocky Hill Greenway Multi-Use Trail

segments.name: BFRT Phase 2B
segments.description: This section is 0.88 miles in Acton and Concord, including a bridge spanning MA Route 2.

links.text: BFRT Phase 2B & 2C Map, with parking, bathrooms, etc.

segments.name: Edgartown to Vineyard Haven
segments.description: The most direct route from Edgartown to Vineyard Haven is the Edgartown-Vineyard-Haven Road, which is a 7-mile trip along a bike path with light, rolling hills.

segments.name: Richard Landry Park footbridge
segments.description: The Richard Landry Park footbridge was installed in 1978 and improved in 2021.

segments.name: South Beach Loop
segments.description: The 3.5 mile ride from the center of Edgartown to South Beach includes a flat and easy bike path once you get a few blocks out of town, with bike racks just before the entrances to South Beach. Continue on to complete the whole loop for an enjoyable and leisurely 7-mile ride.

segments.name: Bike Lane
segments.description: Unprotected but low stress bike line.

segments.name: MCRT Wayside - Fitchburg Connection
segments.description: Dirt path connecting the parking lot to Beaver Brook Reservation.

segments.name: State Forest Loop
segments.description: Cyclists can enjoy this beautiful loop through roughly 10 miles around the State Forest, and a smaller 3-mile loop as well. Both loops have bike paths.

segments.name: BFRT Phase 2C
segments.description: Bruce Freeman Rail Trail Phase 2C is 2.5 miles in Concord, with a short walking section through the West Concord MBTA station.

links.text: BFRT Phase 2B & 2C Map, with parking, bathrooms, etc.

segments.name: Upper Falls Greenway Christina Street Connection
segments.description: It has been suggested by the City of Newton and Newton Conservators that the Christina Street Bridge could be connected to the existing Upper Falls Greenway through its own industrial spur right-of-way, which is currently intact.

segments.name: Christina Street Bridge
segments.description: The Christina Street Bridge is an old railroad spur bridge across the Charles by Christina Street in Newton, though it crosses into Needham. There are efforts to convert the bridge into a trail which are related to the nearby Northland development around Needham Street, as part of it would also be on the east side of the street. The bridge is currently informally usable for walking, but is not bikeable. The bridge connects to the paved Blue Heron Trail in Needham and its formal renovation would provide an additional off-street pedestrian and biking link across the Charles.

segments.name: Blue Heron Trail, Needham
segments.description: A paved trail running by the Charles from Highland Avenue to 4th Avenue, appears to be part of the larger Blue Heron Trail, which is generally a hiking trail, however this section is bikeable.

segments.name: Winterberry Way (On-Road)
segments.description: Low traffic road with parking lot connection, and the ARNWR visitor's center. Also has a sidewalk if necessary.

segments.name: Patrol Road
segments.description:
This was a paved road built for the former U.S. Army base that has deteriorated. However, it is still bikeable, and is the most accessible route from the Assabet River Rail Trail through the Assabet River National Wildlife Refuge.
Note, the northern section of Patrol Road (not shown) is closed.

segments.name: Winterberry Way (Trail)
segments.description: This section recently had a stone-dust improvement, however the northern portion is still dirt trail. Bikeable, non-skinny tires preferred.

segments.name: White Pond Road
segments.description: This was a paved road built for the former U.S. Army base that has deteriorated. However, it is still bikeable, and is the most accessible route from the Assabet River Rail Trail through the Assabet River National Wildlife Refuge.
Low traffic road with parking lot connection.

segments.name: Harry's Way
segments.description: Trail conditions greatly vary on Harry's Way: A deteriorated, paved road, dirt, and a carry-your-bike, hiking-only short stream crossing.

segments.name: Amesbury Riverwalk Connector to the Salisbury Ghost Trail
segments.description:
The City of Amesbury proposes the construction of a 10-foot wide paved shared-use path between the end of the Amesbury-Salisbury Trail Connector project at Elm Street and the east end of the Amesbury Riverwalk at Carriagetown Marketplace. The connection will be approximately a half mile, and will include the construction of a shared-used trail facility for bicycle and pedestrian users and an on-road extension along Elm Street to the Salisbury Ghost Trail. and will include signs, pavement markings, and follow accessibility guidelines.
Construction is funded for the 2027 Transportation Improvement Program for the Merrimack Valley Metropolitan Planning Organization.

As of Spring 2023 the City of Westfield is in the early stages of exploring options for extending its Columbia Greenway to the Southampton line.  Westfield ’s decision on this issue will be an important factor in Southampton’s decision on whether and how to develop a route from Route 10 south to Westfield.
Unsure about the condition of this trail
Grand opening was November 7th, 2025

segments.name: Tri-Community Greenway
segments.description: Quiet road/driveway/bike-path combo

segments.name: Gridley Locks Footpath over the Charles River Dam
segments.description: Walkable, bikes must be walked. Marked unimproved because the Gridley Locks Footpath is not ADA accessible, and can be closed when boats pass.

segments.name: Bill Russell Bridge Protected Bike Lanes
segments.description: The Bill Russell Bridge protected bike lanes opened in July 2025, adjacent to wide pedestrian sidewalks. Note the bike lanes are one-way, however the sidewalks are two-way. On the southbound side there are stairs down to Lovejoy Wharf.

links.text: Video tour of Bill Russell Bridge

segments.name: Leo Birmingham Parkway Shared Use Path
Waltham Sidewalk MCRT
segments.description: While waiting for the MCRT Weston-Waltham Phase 2 project, the gap in Waltham can be travelled entirely using sidewalks and crosswalks.

segments.name: The Missing Link
segments.description: A quick study of the maps of the D&H Rail Trail posted on any of the Vermont D&H kiosks shows a missing section in New York – the maintained Vermont trail ends two miles south of Poultney and then begins again in West Pawlet, 14 miles to the south. The trail does continue north from West Pawlet through Granville and Middle Granville, but this section is not shown on Vermont maps.  There is a route option on quiet roads and the relatively new six-mile section in New York to connect the Poultney and West Pawlet sections of the trail.

segments.name: Neponset Pedestrian Bridge at Osceola Street
segments.description: This pedestrian/bicycle bridge would connect the new Edgewater Greenway to Truman Parkway at Osceola Street in Mattapan. Construction is estimated Summer 2028.

links.text: Neponset Pedestrian Bridge at Osceola Street Public Listening Session

segments.name: Draw 7 On-Road Detour
segments.description: This is DCR's On-Road detour during the Draw 7 Park construction project, until the 2026 opening.

segments.name: Frances Appleton Bridge
segments.description: The Frances Appleton pedestrian bridge linking the Beacon Hill neighborhood to the Esplanade and the popular Hatch Shell is one of the most heavily used footbridges in the state. At 14 feet wide and 750 feet long, it is one of Massachusetts’s longest and most elegant pedestrian bridges. In recognition of this, it won the prestigious Arthur G. Hayden medal, an international award given out once a year. Strong and sustained advocacy made this project possible and led to its being named after the wife of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. The Massachusetts Department of Transportation built the bridge and transferred it to the Department of Conservation and Recreation for care and control.

segments.name: Twin Cities Rail Trail On-Road segment
segments.description: This is on-road, and street signs mark the segment as part of the Twin Cities Rail Trail.

segments.name: Squannacook River Rail Trail | Sidewalk
segments.description: Moving the Squannacook River Rail Trail off the right-of-way beside Harbor Pond for this 800- to 1,000-foot length takes it out of the backyards of some shallow properties, said Town Administrator Andy Sheehan. It will also allow trail users to cross the busy road at a traffic signal.

links.text: Construction begins on the sidewalk connecting the two rail trail sections - May 20, 2025

segments.name: BWALT Segment 5 West Park Drive Extension Project
segments.description: Segment along West Park Drive was completed in August 2024 as part of West Park Drive Extension project.

links.text: Westborough opens part of BWALT trail

segments.name: Charlestown Bridge Northbound to Paul Revere Park
segments.description:
When traveling northbound on the bridge, it can be easier to go down beneath the bridge than to cross the road directly to the park.
Chelsea street is busy, but it's only a short stretch.

segments.name: South Manchester Rail Trail (Airport Section)
segments.description: Local concerns session was held in March 2025. Plan is for a multiuse path alongside multiple roads bypassing the airport.

segments.name: Rockingham Rail Trail Extension
segments.description: Proposal to connect Rockingham Rail Trail to other rail trails in Manchester. Funding/timeline unclear.

segments.name: Border to Boston Newbury Section
segments.description: Rough gravel trail, mostly passable but often flooded in sections. Dead ends at I-95 but you can exit through the Wildlife Management Area

segments.name: Border to Boston Byfield Section
segments.description: Gravel/grass utility corridor, passable on a bike but often overgrown. Dead ends at I-95

segments.name: Derry Rail Trail Shields Brook Bypass
segments.description:
The trail has been graded, but construction is on hold.
A lawsuit between the Committee to Save the Derry Rail Trail Tunnel and the State of New Hampshire challenged the state’s plan to replace the tunnel with an at-grade crossing and bypass trail. In July 2025, a U.S. District Court Judge ruled in favor of the Committee, halting construction of the Interstate 93 Exit 4A project. He directed state and federal highway officials to either reach a compromise or provide empirical evidence that their alternative matches or exceeds the original design’s uninterrupted trail under the new highway.
NHDOT Commissioner Bill Cass stated in an email: “The Department is disappointed by the order. We are working with the NH Attorney General’s Office to determine our next steps.”

segments.name: Windham Greenway
segments.description: Rugged railbed trail passable on gravel and mountain bikes. Can be muddy at times. Includes a lighted tunnel under I-93 that connects near to the Windham Rail Trail

segments.name: Salem Bike/Ped Corridor
segments.description: Gravel powerline corridor that will eventually be paved. Passable with pedestrian signals at all intersections around Tuscan Village including Rockingham Park Blvd.

segments.name: Rockingham Rail Trail - Fremont Branch
segments.description: Short nonmotorized section of the Fremont branch, mostly singletrack, connecting directly to the Windham Rail Trail at the Windham Depot. Travel beyond Route 28 is not recommended as the trail is very sandy due to the ATV traffic.

segments.name: Derry Rail Trail Proposed Tunnel
segments.description: A lawsuit was filed between the Committee to Save the Derry Rail Trail Tunnel and the State of New Hampshire regarding the state's plan to scrap this tunnel in favor of an at-grade crossing and an alternative bypass trail. In July 2025, U.S. District Court Judge Paul J. Barbadoro ruled in favor of the Committee and halted construction of the Interstate 93 Exit 4A project. The judge placed the onus on state and federal highway officials to work out a compromise or come up with empirical evidence that proves their plan is equal to or better than the original design that included an uninterrupted trail under the new highway. NHDOT Commissioner Bill Cass has said via email, “The Department is disappointed by the order. We are working with the NH Attorney General’s Office to determine our next steps.”

segments.name: Rockingham Rail Trail - Fremont Branch
segments.description: Gravel/dirt nonmotorized section of the Fremont Branch. Travel south of 107 is not recommended as the trail is very sandy due to the ATV traffic. Watch for horses, horse prints, and horse manure!

segments.name: Derry Rail Trail Extension
segments.description: Pending completion of Exit 4A construction. Will eventually connect to Londonderry Rail Trail. Passable on a gravel bike with some walking required.

segments.name: Melnea Cass Boulevard Bike Path
segments.description: A sidewalk level bi directional bike lane along Melnea Cass Boulevard. The western end of the path is accessible from the Southwest Corridor Path, at the intersection of Columbus and Melnea Cass.

segments.name: Bi Directional Seperated Bike Lane along Ames Street
segments.description: The bi directional bike lane is separated by flex posts. The southern terminus connects to the Charles River Bike Path and the northern terminus connects to the Kittie Knox Bike Path.

segments.name: Rutherford Avenue Linear Park
segments.description: The off road linear park along Rutherford Avenue is currently at 25% design. It is planned to include bike and pedestrian paths and is expected to be completed by 2032.

links.text: Learn more about the Rutherford Avenue Linear Park and other projects nearby

segments.name: Grand Junction Multi Use Path
segments.description: A completed part of the Grand Junction Multi Use Path

links.text: Learn more about the Grand Junction Multi Use Path

segments.name: Commercial Street/Atlantic Avenue Bike Path
segments.description: The Commercial Street portion is a sidewalk level bidirectional bike lane whilst the Atlantic Avenue section is a bidirectional bike lane (street level) separated by a narrow curb. There are several connections to the Boston Harborwalk, as well. Part of the Connect Historic Boston Bike Trail.

segments.name: John W. Weeks Memorial Bridge
segments.description:
The John W. Weeks Memorial Bridge, usually called the Weeks Footbridge or simply Weeks Bridge, is a pedestrian bridge over the Charles River. The Weeks Bridge opened in 1927 to carry pedestrian traffic between the Harvard Business School's newly built Allston campus and Harvard's main campus in Cambridge. It is named for John W. Weeks, a longtime U.S. Representative and later U.S. Senator from Massachusetts, and the U.S. Secretary of War in the Harding and Coolidge administrations.
On September 21, 2015, the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation held a ribbon cutting to mark completion of a $3 million renovation that made the Weeks bridge handicap accessible in compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act. Stairs at either end were replaced with ramps and accessibility-compliant railings were installed on the bridge. Other improvements included new accessible approach paths, new lighting using replicated historic fixtures, restoring the eroded river bank adjacent to the bridge, and repairs to the bridge masonry and structure.

segments.name: Boston Harborwalk-Bike Friendly Segment
segments.description: Boston and MassDOT maps recognize this sidewalk-like section of the Harbor Walk as a shared used path where bikes are allowed. The part around Columbia Point (JFK Library, UMass) is quieter and asphalt, while other sections are concrete and have more traffic.

links.text: Learn more about the Boston Harborwalk

segments.name: Kittie Knox Bike Path
segments.description: Parallel to the Loughrey Walkway, where bikes are explicitly prohibited.

segments.name: Metacomet Greenway
segments.description: The Metacomet Greenway is a proposed trail that utilizes the Old Colony Railroad corridor. Currently, the trail is in its initial stages and the route shown is probably not be the finalized route due to unknown and/or unexpected factors. You can see the proposed route in the link below.

links.text: Learn more and support the Metacomet Greenway

segments.name: Porous Pavement
segments.description: This is a narrow path and bikes are allowed, but asked to stop for pedestrians. Part of Watertown Riverfront Charles River Road Phase II project.

links.text: Watertown Riverfront Charles River Road Phase II Construction Public Information Meeting 12/9/2021

segments.description: Check out the adjacent Watertown Riverfront Park while on this stone dust section of the Chares River Bike Path.

segments.name: Watertown Riverfront Charles River Road Phase II

links.text: Watertown Riverfront Charles River Road Phase II Construction Public Information Meeting 12/9/2021

segments.name: North Point Park and Shared Use Paths
segments.description:
North Point Park is an 8.5-acre park located along the left bank of the Charles River on the border of Cambridge and Boston, Massachusetts, created as mitigation for the taking of planned parkland for the construction of the Big Dig.
The shared use path passes the Lynch Family Skate Park.
Part of the Mass Central Rail Trail.

segments.name: Cambridge Crossing
segments.description: The North Point neighborhood of Boston converted a former rail yard into Cambridge Crossing, a mixed use development including a shared use path. It is part of the Mass Central Rail Trail.

segments.name: Waltham Riverwalk
segments.description: This section of the Charles River Bike Path in Waltham was recently reconstructed with ARPA funds.

segments.name: North Bank Bridge
segments.description:
The North Bank Bridge is a pedestrian and bicycle bridge on the north bank of the Charles River in Massachusetts. The bridge was built as a Big Dig mitigation.
It is part of the Mass Central Rail Trail.

segments.name: Phase 1A, Rabbit Run Rail Trail
segments.description: The Town of Athol has been awarded a Mass Trails Grant for work associated with Phase 1 of the Rabbit Run Rail Trail (RRRT). Phase 1A and Phase 1B have been separated.

segments.name: Town Lane
segments.description: This 1 mile multi-use path connects the midtown Nantucket to the downtown area. The path starts on the Milestone rotary, continues on Orange Street, exit to the right around the back og Goose Pond, to Washington Street.

segments.name: Yankee Doodle Bike Path Phase 2
segments.description: Phase 2 is in preliminary design. It will connect Phase 1 at the Middlesex Turnpike/Concord Road intersection to an existing bike path at Billerica Memorial High School.

segments.name: Sparks Avenue Path
segments.description:
A multi-use path of 0.65 miles that connects the Sparks Avenue rotary to Surfside Road by the Nantucket High School.
Along the road, you will find: 
Downy Flake 
Cumberland Farms 
Stop and Shop 
The Sea Grill 
Nantucket Boys and Girls Club 
Nantucket Public Schools
Nantucket Community Pool

segments.name: Clark Street Bridge
segments.description:
The Clark Street Bridge, built in 1908 by the Boston and Maine Railroad, is a 6 foot wide pedestrian bridge over the MBTA tracks in Belmont.
The Bridge will serve as an access point to the Belmont Community Path, but will not be improved as part of the path project. A bridge must be 8 feet wide for MassDOT path fundability. Widening the bridge would result in loss of its grandfathered status as an 18-foot clearance bridge that preceded the MBTA’s change to a 22.5-foot clearance standard. It is possible that a waiver could be obtained, but not certain. If not, raising the bridge 4.5 feet above its current height would require substantial grading on the south side, possibly including a switchback ramp, to meet ADA requirements. The cost of those changes has been estimated to approach the cost of a new bridge.

links.text: Community Path Could Have Bridge, Box

segments.name: Arthur Fiedler Footbridge
segments.description: The Arthur Fiedler Footbridge is a brutalist style bridge. It was named to commemorate the 25th anniversary of Boston Pops Orchestra public performances on the Charles River Esplanade. Conductor Arthur Fiedler, who led the Pops from 1930 to 1979, spearheaded the campaign to bring music to the Esplanade. He conducted the first public concert at the site of the Hatch Shell in 1929 and continued to lead the Pops in regular public performances at that site until he retired.

segments.name: Richard McKinnon Park and Shared Use Paths
segments.description:
Richard McKinnon Park is an 8.5-acre park located along the left bank of the Charles River on the border of Cambridge and Boston, Massachusetts, created as mitigation for the taking of planned parkland for the construction of the Big Dig.
The shared use path passes the Lynch Family Skate Park.
